prompt: What's the story behind the 1904 St. Louis World's Fair?
title: Why Was the 1904 Fair Called "White City"?
originalTitle: The 1904 St. Louis World’s Fair (Louisiana Purchase Exposition)
socialQuestion: Why Was the 1904 Fair Called "White City"?
pullQuotes: "Over 60 nations and 43 U.S. states and territories mounted exhibits across the 1,200-acre fairgrounds, drawing nearly 19.7 million visitors over seven months."
"Fair planners openly sought to promote America’s role as an overseas imperial power, using exhibits to argue that Western colonial expansion was uplifting 'primitive' peoples."
"The result was an exposition that showed the world of tomorrow through an American lens."
"Similarly, Native American groups (such as Apache and Pueblo peoples), African pygmies, East Asians, and others were showcased in what were essentially 'human zoos'."
"In short, the fair was a living encyclopedia of human achievement and a carnival of modern wonders, all in one."
sceneDescription: A bustling promenade with sweeping neoclassical facades under a blinding midday sun. Groups of turn-of-the-century visitors in straw boaters and high collars peer up at towering white pavilions. One frazzled groundskeeper stands precariously on a tall ladder, painting a small smudge back to pristine white. A sense of awe and fleeting spectacle lingers in the air as the temporary grandeur sparkles in the heat.
